node.contents: The following Java code generates the following JVM bytecode.

node.contents: I'm curious why the code from offset 31 to offset 36 is generated. Nothing in the JLS7 or JVM7 specification talks about this. Did I miss anything?

astNode.text: I'm curious why the code from offset 31 to offset 36 is generated. Nothing in the JLS7 or JVM7 specification talks about this. Did I miss anything?

node.contents: Even if I remove the println statements, the code (offset 31 to offset 36) still get generated, only at an earlier location, since the println call has been removed.

astNode.text: Even if I remove the println statements, the code (offset 31 to offset 36) still get generated, only at an earlier location, since the println call has been removed.

node.contents: Hello Peter, your answer doesn't answer the question: "I'm curious why the code ... is generated" or even "Did I miss anything?". Thank you for your participation though.

astNode.text: Hello Peter, your answer doesn't answer the question: "I'm curious why the code ... is generated" or even "Did I miss anything?". Thank you for your participation though.

node.contents: The code is generated because there has to be code to release the lock, see my example. You missed my attempt to explain. ;)

astNode.text: The code is generated because there has to be code to release the lock, see my example. You missed my attempt to explain. ;)

node.contents: It was to clarify exactly what is happening. I assumed you might be more familar with java code than byte code.

astNode.text: It was to clarify exactly what is happening. I assumed you might be more familar with java code than byte code.

node.contents: Rene's explanation is better. Also, note that I didn't ask for an alternative way. Thanks, anyway.

astNode.text: Rene's explanation is better. Also, note that I didn't ask for an alternative way. Thanks, anyway.

node.contents: I don't know where it is in the JLS, but it must say somewhere that when an exception is thrown, a lock is released. You can do this with Unsafe.monitorEnter/Exit

astNode.text: I don't know where it is in the JLS, but it must say somewhere that when an exception is thrown, a lock is released. You can do this with Unsafe.monitorEnter/Exit

elements.contents: void testMonitor() { Boolean x = new Boolean(false); theUnsafe.monitorEnter(x); try { System.out.println("inside synchronized"); System.out.println("blah"); } catch(Throwable t) { theUnsafe.monitorExit(x); throw t; }; theUnsafe.monitorExit(x); System.out.println("done"); }

units.rawText: void testMonitor() { Boolean x = new Boolean(false); theUnsafe.monitorEnter(x); try { System.out.println("inside synchronized"); System.out.println("blah"); } catch(Throwable t) { theUnsafe.monitorExit(x); throw t; }; theUnsafe.monitorExit(x); System.out.println("done"); }

node.contents: I believe there is a catch block table at the end you may be missing.

astNode.text: I believe there is a catch block table at the end you may be missing.

node.contents: The compiler adds an invisible try/catch block here, to ensure the monitor state gets released (which is documented in the VM specs, see bottom of post). You can verify this by using javap -v and look at the exception table:

astNode.text: The compiler adds an invisible try/catch block here, to ensure the monitor state gets released (which is documented in the VM specs, see bottom of post). You can verify this by using javap -v and look at the exception table:

node.contents: Normally, a compiler for the Java programming language ensures that the lock operation implemented by a monitorenter instruction executed prior to the execution of the body of the synchronized statement is matched by an unlock operation implemented by a monitorexit instruction whenever the synchronized statement completes, whether completion is normal or abrupt.

astNode.text: Normally, a compiler for the Java programming language ensures that the lock operation implemented by a monitorenter instruction executed prior to the execution of the body of the synchronized statement is matched by an unlock operation implemented by a monitorexit instruction whenever the synchronized statement completes, whether completion is normal or abrupt.
